stream_context.summary: Kaze iterates on the second segment of the first overworld, focusing on player flow (coin availability, navigation without demanding advanced moves) and brainstorms natural barriers (fruit/trees/ruins) to avoid “walling off” the island. A major chunk becomes a technical design session: prototyping a ghost-ship ‘fog gate’ that gets denser as the player looks at/approaches the ship, culminating in a fade-to-white + respawn until the lighthouse is activated. He also gives a notable ‘state of the engine’ update (how much is already custom vs vanilla SM64) and discusses commissioned side projects and cautious beta testing to prevent leaks.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains a meaningful design/tech inflection for the overworld’s ghost-ship gate (a concrete plan + partial implementation for N64-feasible fog behavior) plus unusually candid clarification that the project is effectively a custom engine/OS effort (including replacing libultra) and what would be required for legal sellability. Also reveals business reality: commissioned ROMhack work vs RTY as passion/free.

findings.summary: Kaze’s core goal for the first overworld is to increase collectible coin availability without making collection feel tedious, and to add clearer ‘invites’ (like placing coin stacks) that subtly teach players where to go.
He wants traversal solutions that don’t assume players know SM64 techniques like wallkicks; he considers adding walk-up rock formations or other gentle ramps rather than move-gated progression.

Overworld macro-plan: the hub is split into ~15 parts; Part 3 (beach) includes the zoo entrance and a ghost-ship area. The ghost ship is initially inaccessible via fog, and later becomes accessible after a lighthouse interaction clears/weakens the fog—creating a deliberate ‘do something later to unlock something earlier’ loop.

He’s actively trying to avoid the island feeling like it’s segmented by constant cliff walls; he brainstormes ‘natural’ blockers (tree lines/forests, giant fruit like bananas, ruins/destroyed castles as platformable barriers) to keep the hub cohesive while still guiding routing.

He prototypes a ship-area fog system constrained by N64 realities: fog should be weak when looking away, stronger when looking toward the ship, intensify as the ship fills more of the screen, and culminate in a screen-wide white fade followed by a “washed ashore” respawn until the lighthouse is activated. Implementation involves combining distance-based fade curves with camera-angle-based intensity and smoothing the curve (squaring) to avoid abrupt transitions.

Tooling limitation: his fog preview workflow is hampered by a hard cap (can’t preview fog beyond a certain value, ~1000), forcing him to iterate with imperfect preview or live testing rather than accurately visualizing intended long-range fog.

Engine status update: Kaze claims most of what’s running is now ‘his engine,’ with major systems rewritten (rendering changes like 3D coins, custom camera, custom skybox approach, refactored movement on slopes, custom collision/step functions, altered swimming controls, quaternion-based animation plans). He’s also reworking the underlying OS layer and intends to remove libultra, which he calls unoptimized.
findings.quote: Almost all of this engine here is my engine at this point. The only really thing that's still left from the vanilla 64 is Mario's physics.

findings.summary: He differentiates RTY as passion/free work versus other ROMhacks built in his ‘engine/style’ being commissions (including “Drug Boss Mario,” described as an FPS with drug dealing, police shooting, and an illicit-substance stock market sim). He recruits a small first wave of trusted beta testers to reduce leak risk, then plans to broaden testing later.

He articulates a design principle: sometimes the least-liked elements can be structurally necessary to make the overall game’s contrast and pacing work—applied to his feelings about certain courses/segments needing variety even if imperfect.
findings.quote: Sometimes the part that people least like about the game are also the parts that are most necessary to make the game's design work.

biobak.summary: Kaze references an expected ‘final rework’ pass by Biobak on the overworld/levels and temporarily imports simpler backgrounds to make current layout iteration easier while waiting on that rework.

key_stories.title: Designing the ghost-ship fog gate (lighthouse unlock)
key_stories.summary: Kaze wants the overworld to support satisfying ‘later unlocks earlier’ progression, using a ghost ship that’s visible but unreachable until a lighthouse event changes the world state. The stream turns into an on-the-fly R&D session on how to sell ‘volumetric’ fog on N64 without tanking performance.
key_stories.challenge: Make an intimidating fog barrier around the ghost ship that looks convincing, communicates ‘not yet,’ and prevents players from brute-forcing entry—within N64 rendering limits (no true volumetrics; performance-sensitive overdraw).
key_stories.process: He rejects heavy plane-stacks as too expensive, explores distance-based and screen-space fade approaches, then implements a combined model: fog intensity depends on both distance to ship and camera angle (strong when looking at ship; weaker when looking away), with a final full-screen white fade and a respawn/wash-ashore behavior when entering a ship radius pre-unlock.
key_stories.outcome: He gets a version ‘working’ but continues tuning curve smoothness, ship readability, and notes the need for a later VFX pass (e.g., additional effects around the ship) and background/skybox considerations to make the illusion hold.
key_stories.key_quote: You enter this area, and when you look at the ship, there's going to be very strong fog in this area.

key_stories.title: RTY as a custom-engine project (and what ‘sellable’ would require)
key_stories.summary: While answering engine/port questions, Kaze clarifies how far RTY has diverged from vanilla SM64 and frames it as largely rewritten tech. He also outlines what would still block legal sellability: remaining SM64-derived elements like Mario/sound engine and remnants of libultra.
key_stories.challenge: Build new gameplay/visual systems on original hardware while shedding legacy SM64 systems that limit flexibility or aesthetics (e.g., camera, skybox) and potentially remove legally sensitive components if commercialization were ever desired.
key_stories.process: He describes replacing rendering approaches (coins, skyboxes), rewriting camera and physics sub-functions, changing swim controls, and reworking OS infrastructure—explicitly planning to remove libultra due to optimization/quality concerns.
key_stories.outcome: The project’s technical identity is positioned less as a ‘ROMhack’ and more as a bespoke N64 game built on top of decomp roots, with a clear list of remaining subsystems that would need replacement for a fully independent/shippable product.
key_stories.key_quote: If I wanted this to be legally sellable, I would have to update the sound engine… and I’m going to remove all of libultra.

open_questions.topic: Ghost ship + lighthouse gating: final player experience
open_questions.context: Kaze prototypes a fog system that depends on distance and camera angle and uses a fade-to-white + wash-ashore respawn until the lighthouse is activated, then shifts to lighter fog for atmosphere.
questions: What did you want players to feel the first time they see the ship—curiosity, fear, mystery—and how did that emotion drive the exact mechanics (camera-based fog, forced respawn) you chose?
How did you decide where the ‘respawn radius’ starts, and how did you test whether it feels like a natural force (fog/current) versus an arbitrary invisible wall?
What’s the intended ‘after’ state once the lighthouse is activated—complete clarity, mild atmospheric haze, or a new kind of threat—and why?

open_questions.topic: Natural barriers vs ‘cliff walls’ in a cohesive island hub
open_questions.context: Kaze dislikes the hub being ringed by cliffs and brainstormes alternatives (fruit, forests, ruins/destroyed castles) that still guide routing without feeling artificial.
questions: What rules do you use to decide when a barrier should be diegetic (trees/fruit/ruins) versus explicit (cliffs/walls), and how do you ensure players still read the intended path quickly?
Did any barrier ideas (fruit, forest, ruins) create unexpected navigation or camera problems on N64 that forced you back toward ‘boring’ cliffs?
How much do you want the overworld to be ‘learnable’ at a glance versus intentionally confusing/mysterious to encourage exploration?

open_questions.topic: ‘Mostly my engine now’: independence, libultra removal, and legal sellability
open_questions.context: Kaze says RTY has rewritten major systems and he’s reworking the OS to remove libultra; he also claims legal sellability would require replacing Mario and the sound engine.
questions: When did you realize RTY wasn’t just a ROMhack anymore, but effectively a new engine/game—and was that an intentional goal or an emergent consequence of solving problems?
What are the hardest remaining ‘vanilla’ dependencies to replace (Mario actions, audio, remaining OS pieces), and what tradeoffs might that force on the game’s feel?
Do you actually want RTY to ever be ‘legally sellable,’ or is this more about technical pride and long-term maintainability?
